protocol_name: Protocols from: Invasion genetics of the silver carp (Hypophthalmichthys molitrix) across North America: Differentiation of fronts, introgression, and eDNA detection
protocol_name_html: Protocols from: Invasion genetics of the silver carp (Hypophthalmichthys molitrix) across North America: Differentiation of fronts, introgression, and eDNA detection
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"cgu6d","text":"This protocol describes the data collection and analysis performed in \"Invasion genetics of the silver carp (Hypophthalmichthys molitrix) across North America: Differentiation of fronts, introgression, and eDNA detection\". Published in PLOS One, 2018.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":109,"length":27,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7jgd8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a13vi","text":"The invasive silver carp Hypophthalmichthys molitrix escaped from southern U.S. aquaculture during the 1970s to spread throughout the Mississippi River basin and steadily moved northward, now reaching the threshold of the Laurentian Great Lakes. The silver carp is native to eastern Asia and is a large, prolific filter-feeder that decreases food availability for fisheries. The present study evaluates its population genetic variability and differentiation across the introduced range using 10 nuclear DNA microsatellite loci, sequences of two mitochondrial genes (cytochrome b and cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1), and a nuclear gene (ribosomal protein S7 gene intron 1). Populations are analyzed from two invasion fronts threatening the Great Lakes (the Illinois River outside Lake Michigan and the Wabash River, leading into the Maumee River and western Lake Erie), established areas in the southern and central Mississippi River, and a later Missouri River colonization. Results discern considerable genetic diversity and some significant population differentiation, with greater mtDNA haplotype diversity and unique microsatellite alleles characterizing the southern populations. Invasion fronts significantly differ, diverging from the southern Mississippi River population. About 3% of individuals contain a unique and very divergent mtDNA haplotype (primarily the southerly populations and the Wabash River), which may stem from historic introgression in Asia with female largescale silver carp H. harmandi. Nuclear microsatellites and S7 sequences of the introgressed individuals do not significantly differ from silver carp. MtDNA variation is used in a high-throughput sequence assay that identifies and distinguishes invasive carp species and their population haplotypes (including H. molitrix and H. harmandi) at all life stages, in application to environmental (e)DNA water and plankton samples. We discerned silver and bighead carp eDNA from 10 bait shops in the Great Lakes watershed, indicating that release from retailers comprises another likely vector. Our findings provide key baseline population genetic data for understanding and tracing the invasion’s progression, facilitating detection, and evaluating future trajectory and adaptive success.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":25,"length":27,"style":"italic"},{"offset":577,"length":1,"style":"italic"},{"offset":594,"length":1,"style":"italic"},{"offset":1503,"length":11,"style":"italic"},{"offset":1794,"length":12,"style":"italic"},{"offset":1810,"length":11,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"32o0f","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
protocol_affiliation: NOAA Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory,Independent,University of Toledo, NOAA Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory

keywords: Invasion genetics, population genetics, introgression, PCR, mitochondrial DNA, sequencing, microsatellites, environmental DNA, eDNA

authors_list.name: Matthew Snyder
authors_list.affiliation: University of Toledo, NOAA Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory

status_info: These protocols are working and are published in many other Stepien articles.

steps.data: {"blocks":[{"key":"63u3a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5a5n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8mqjr","text":"Tissue samples are collected under University of Toledo IACUC protocol #205400, \u201cGenetic studies for fishery management\u201d to CAS. Samples are individually labeled, stored in 95% EtOH, and archived at the NOAA Pacific Marine Environmental Laboratory.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8aibs","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"54c35","text":"Genomic DNA is extracted and purified from the EtOH fixed tissues using DNeasy\u00ae Blood and Tissue Kits (Qiagen Inc., Valencia, CA USA), quality checked on 1% agarose mini\u2013gels stained with ethidium bromide, and assessed with a Nanodrop\u2122 spectrophotometer (Thermo Scientific, Bothell, WA, USA).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[],"guid":"9E4C44D0DC6B11E8BDF9597FDCE450B9","id":678259,"previous_guid":null,"section":"Sample collection"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6r83t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2ufs8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"3v3tb","text":"PCR reactions contain 25\u00b5L of 1.25 units AmpliTaq\u00ae DNA polymerase, 1X GeneAmp\u00ae PCR Buffer I, 250\u00b5M dNTPs, 0.5uM (cytb) or 1\u00b5M (COI) of each primer, and 2\u00b5L of \u226530ng\/\u03bcL of DNA template, and ddH2O. Conditions are 3 min at 94\u02daC, followed by 34 cycles of 95\u02daC for 30 sec, 40 sec at T\u00ada (see appropriate publication), and 72\u02daC for 45 sec, capped by 5 min at 72\u02daC.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":278,"length":3,"style":"italic"},{"offset":280,"length":1,"style":"sub"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cgdie","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"cksum","text":"PCR product aliquots (4\u00b5L) are visualized on 1% agarose mini-gels stained with ethidium bromide and successful reactions are purified with QIAquick\u00ae PCR Purification Kits (Qiagen) and quantified via Nanodrop. Sanger DNA sequencing is outsourced to the Cornell University Life Sciences Core Laboratories Center (http:\/\/cores.lifesciences.cornell.edu\/brcinfo\/) and MCLAB (http:\/\/www.mclab.com\/DNA-Sequencing-Services.html), which use ABI Automated 3730 DNA Analyzers. Sample preparation for sequencing is as recommended by sequencing facility in protocols available on their websites. Sequences are quality scored, manually checked, and aligned by us with Codon Code Aligner v7.01 (Codon Corp.).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"fa2op","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"b1jb","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9tuth","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"8nh1t","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[],"guid":"70A5E8A0DC6C11E8BDF9597FDCE450B9","id":678260,"previous_guid":"9E4C44D0DC6B11E8BDF9597FDCE450B9","section":"DNA Sequencing"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8g1u9","text":"Genetic variation was analyzed at 10 nuclear DNA microsatellite loci, including Hmo1 and Hmo11 from Mia et al. 2005, Ar201 from Cheng et al. 2007, and HmoB4, B5, D8, D213, D240, D243, and D246 from King et al. 2011. 10\u00b5L polymerase chain reactions (PCR) contain 0.35 units AmpliTaq\u00ae DNA polymerase (ABI; Applied Biosystems\u00e4, Foster City, CA, USA), 1X GeneAmp\u00ae PCR buffer I (ABI), 80\u00b5M total dNTPs, 0.4mM spermadine, 0.52\u00b5M of each primer, and 2\u00b5L of \u226530ng\/\u00b5l DNA and ddH2O. PCR was conducted on C1000 thermal cyclers (Bio\u2013Rad Laboratories, Hercules, CA) with 2 min initial denaturation at 94\u00b0C, followed by 39 cycles of 40 sec denaturation at 94\u00b0C, 40 sec annealing (at 52\u00b0C for the Mia et al. 2005 primers, 58\u00b0C for the Cheng et al. 2007 primers, and 56\u00b0C for the King et al. 2011 sets), and 1 min 72\u00b0C extension, capped by 10 min final 72\u00b0C extension. Amplification products are diluted 1:50 with ddH2O, of which 2\u00b5L are added to 13\u00b5L solution of formamide and ABI GeneScan\u00e4\u2013500 LIZ\u00ae size standard, and loaded into 96-well plates. Microsatellite products are denatured for 2 min at 95\u02daC and analyzed on our ABI 3130xl Genetic Analyzer with GeneMapper\u00ae 4.0 software (ABI). Output profiles are checked manually to confirm allelic size variants.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":80,"length":4,"style":"italic"},{"offset":89,"length":5,"style":"italic"},{"offset":104,"length":6,"style":"italic"},{"offset":117,"length":5,"style":"italic"},{"offset":134,"length":6,"style":"italic"},{"offset":151,"length":32,"style":"italic"},{"offset":188,"length":4,"style":"italic"},{"offset":687,"length":6,"style":"italic"},{"offset":727,"length":6,"style":"italic"},{"offset":770,"length":6,"style":"italic"},{"offset":281,"length":1,"style":"sup"},{"offset":358,"length":1,"style":"sup"},{"offset":984,"length":1,"style":"sup"},{"offset":1152,"length":1,"style":"sup"},{"offset":470,"length":1,"style":"sub"},{"offset":902,"length":1,"style":"sub"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"ef7e8","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"937fs","text":"Mia MY, Taggart J, Gilmour AE, Gheyas AA, Das TK, Kohinoor AHM, et al. Detection of hybridization between Chinese carp species (Hypophthalmichthys molitrix and Aristichthys nobilis) in hatchery broodstock in Bangladesh using DNA microsatellite loci. Aquaculture. 2005; 247:267\u2013273. https:\/\/doi.org\/10.1016\/j.aquaculture.2005.02.018","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":128,"length":27,"style":"italic"},{"offset":160,"length":20,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"2q752","text":"Cheng L, Liu L, Yu X, Tong J. Sixteen polymorphic microsatellites in bighead carp (Aristichthys nobilis) and cross-amplification in silver carp (Hypophthalmichthys moltrix). Mol Ecol Res. 2007; 8:656\u2013658. https:\/\/doi.org\/10.1111\/j.1471-8286.2007.02037.x","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":83,"length":20,"style":"italic"},{"offset":145,"length":27,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bfjqe","text":"King TL, Eackles MS, Chapman, DC. Tools for assessing kinship, population structure, phylogeography, and interspecific hybridization in Asian carps invasive to the Mississippi River, USA: isolation and characterization of novel tetranucleotide microsatellite DNA loci in silver carp Hypophthalmichthys molitrix. Cons Gen Res. 2011; 3:397\u2013401. https:\/\/doi.org\/10.1007\/s12686-010-9285-3","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":283,"length":27,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[],"guid":"BB2FF0A0DC6C11E8BDF9597FDCE450B9","id":678261,"previous_guid":"70A5E8A0DC6C11E8BDF9597FDCE450B9","section":"Microsatellite Data Collection"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8ou5h","text":"Approximately two dozen bait fish are purchased from each bait shop, which are immediately sacrificed in the parking lot using the University of Toledo IACUC procedure. The water containing the fish is drained into a sterile container, placed on ice, and then frozen at -80\u00b0C in the laboratory. We centrifuge 250 ml of the water from each shop at 4500 rpm and 4\u00b0C, for 45 min. This is accomplished by splitting the sample into five 50 ml tubes. The supernatant is poured off and the pellet, containing extra and intracellular DNA and debris, is is gathered from each tube and resuspended using 1 ml of 95% ethanol and stored at -20\u00b0C until DNA extraction using Qiagen DNeasy kits following the manufactures protocol except two AW1 and AW2 washes are performed for each sample. Each extraction is subjected to a Zymo OneStep PCR Inhibitor Removal Kit (Zymo Genetics, Seattle, WA). Negative centrifugation controls were processed using reverse osmosis deionized water and the same protocol as above.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[],"guid":"EB984BA0DC6E11E8BDF9597FDCE450B9","id":678263,"previous_guid":"BB2FF0A0DC6C11E8BDF9597FDCE450B9","section":"eDNA sample collection"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"8216p","text":"Our invasive carp assay uses forward primer 5\u2019\u2013TGATGAAAYTTYGGMTCYCTHCTAGG \u20133\u2019 and reverse primer 5\u2019\u2013AARAAGAATGATGCYCCRTTRGC \u20133\u2019 to amplify a 135bp region beginning at base 114 in cytochrome b. Each primer set has 4 unique combinations of sapcer inserts between 4 and 18 bases that increase overall run diversity. 25\u00b5l PCR reactions consist of 1x Radiant TAQ Reaction Buffer (Alkali Scientific Inc., Ft. Lauderdale, FL), 3mM MgCl2, 1mM total dNTPs, 0.6mM of each primer (with spacer inserts and an Illumina\u00ae, MiSeq sequencing primer tail), and 1.25 units of Radiant TAQ polymerase. The final PCR step uses the prior step\u2019s column-cleaned product as template (2\u00b5l) and incorporated Nextera paired end indices (Illumina\u00ae, kit FC-121-1011), which include the P5 and P7 adaptor sequences, allowing the prepared library to bind onto the surface of the Illumina\u00ae MiSeq flowcell. Adding unique index combinations permits multiple samples to be pooled together in each MiSeq lane. No template controls (NTCs) are amplified for each reaction, and only libraries that lack NTC amplification are used for MiSeq analyses.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":505,"length":1,"style":"sup"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"pdv1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"35l9h","text":"After column clean up, products are sized and quantified in our laboratory on a 2100 Bioanalyzer using a DNA 1000 chip (Agilent Technologies), prior to Illumina\u00ae MiSeq analysis by Ohio State University\u2019s Molecular and Cellular Imaging Center in Wooster, OH (http:\/\/mcic.osu.edu\/). Concentrations of pooled products were measured with a Qubit fluorometer (Invitrogen) and with the Bioanalyzer. Pooled samples were run on an Illumina\u00ae MiSeq with 2X 300 bp V3 chemistry. An additional 40\u201350% PhiX DNA spike-in control was added to improve data quality of low nucleotide diversity samples","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[],"guid":"5E7EF7E0DC6F11E8BDF9597FDCE450B9","id":678264,"previous_guid":"EB984BA0DC6E11E8BDF9597FDCE450B9","section":"eDNA library preparation"}

{"blocks":[{"key":"1bms","text":"Custom eDNA analysis scripts are available in the Dryad repository (doi:10.5061\/dryad.92h1f12).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"aljub","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"djbi2","text":"Primers were trimmed with the script CarpTrimPrimers.pl. This script also removes detectable incidinces of index hopping by removing reads with the wrong spacer primer.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6dt4o","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7khke","text":"Merging of reads was done in DADA2 in R folloing with standard protocol except during the filter and trim step the trunc.len function was ommitted and the max.e was set to (3,5). Chimeras were removed with DADA2.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"6kcu9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"bfste","text":"BlastCylce500.pl BLASTed all results files against two custom databases. One of all cytochrome b sequences from actinopterygii on GenBank and another of those only from fishes currently present or predicted invaders of the Great Lakes. MorphVeDNASummarize.pl compares observed species hits to advertised species and those sampled with morphology. This script requires several input files also available in the github repository.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":95,"length":1,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[],"guid":"B0B63000DC7E11E8BDF9597FDCE450B9","id":678282,"previous_guid":"5E7EF7E0DC6F11E8BDF9597FDCE450B9","section":"custom eDNA analysis scripts"}
